question.name: 1.2.2.3 Laws of indices cont
question.questiontext:
Two important results which can be derived from the laws of indices state:

Key Point

  • Any non-zero number raised to the power \(0\) has the value \(1\) , that is \(a^0=1\).
  • Any number raised to power \(1\) is itself, that is \(a^1=a\).

A generalisation of the third law of indices states:

Key Point

\((a^mb^n)^k = a^{mk}b^{nk}\) .

Example

Remove the brackets from

  1. \((3x)^2\)
  2. \((x^3y^7)^4\)

Solution

  1. Noting that \(3=3^1\) and \(x=x^1\) then \((3x)^2= (3^1x^1)^2 = 3^2x^2=9x^2\).
    Alternatively \((3x)^2=(3x)\times (3x) = 9x^2\).
  2. \((x^3y^7)^4 = x^{3\times 4}y^{7\times 4} = x^{12}y^{28}\).
